body.p: Aloft he guards the starry folds Who is the brother of the star; The bird whose joy is in the wind Exultleth in the war.

No painted plume—a sober hue, His beauty is his power; That eager calm of gaze intent Foresees the SibylSee use of "Sibylline" in "Formerly a Slave" (intertextual) https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sibyl (reference)'s hour.

Austere, he crowns the swaying perch, Flapped by the angry flag; The hurricane from the battery sings, But his claw has known the crag"Doth the eagle mount up at thy command, and make her nest on high? She dwelleth and abideth on the rock, upon the crag of the rock, and the strong place....Her young ones suck up blood and where the slain are, there is she." Job 39: 28 (27-30) (Cohen 256) [reference, biblical]See Tennyson’s 1851 fragment poem, “The Eagle”: “He clasps the crag with crooked hands / Close to the sun in lonely lands / Ringed by the azure world, he stands. / The wrinkled sea beneath him crawls, / He watches from his mountain walls, / And like a thunderbolt he falls.” [Robin Smith].

Amid the scream of shells, his scream Runs shrilling; and the glare Of eyes that brave the blinding sun"if eagles gaze at the sun, may not men at the Gods?" Mardi (chapter 135) (Cohen 256) [intertextual] "Few grand poets have good eyes; for they needs blind must be, who ever gaze upon the sun. (Mardi, chapter 180) (Published Poems 654) "do eagles wear spectacles?" (Published Poems 654; Shakespeare's Dramatic Works, Vol 7, Melville's Marginalia The vollied flame can bear.
The pride of quenchless strength is his— Strength which, though chained, avails; The very rebel looks and thrills— The anchored Emblem hails.
Though scarred in many a furious fray, No deadly hurt he knew; Well may we think his years are charmed— The Eagle of the Blue.
